sentence: Stocks racked up significant losses Wednesday in another brutal session as the lack of a bottom in oil and concerns about the U.S. economy continued to plague Wall Street.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell to its lowest level in more than three months with component stocks Home Depot ( HD ), JP Morgan ( JPM ) and Goldman Sachs ( GS ) taking the brunt of a 300-plus point decline in the blue-chip index.
The Nasdaq was the biggest loser with a 3.4% drop on heavy losses in biotech and technology stocks.
And although all ten sectors of the S&P 500 were in the red, defensive stocks like utilities and telecoms were insulated from the worst of today's selling pressure.
Trading kicked off with the major benchmark indices higher thanks to upbeat Chinese trade data and a 2% gain in oil.

But when oil started to retrace gains as a result of EIA inventory data, stocks fell in sympathy with losses accelerating later in the day in the wake of a lackluster Beige Book report on the economy from the Federal Reserve.
The Beige Book indicated that while there was economic expansion in 9 of the 12 Fed districts, the manufacturing and energy sector continues to struggle, and wages remain flat.
There was little in the report to indicate that the economy can tolerate another rate hike, especially as weak demand from overseas dampens U.S. manufacturing activity.
Thursday's economic data includes weekly initial jobless claims, expected to fall 2,000 to 275,000, as well as December import (-1.4%) and export (-0.5%) prices.

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(+) NHTC (+11.47%) Refuted allegations that company is under investigation in China, raising share buyback program

(-) ESPR (-14.38%) Initiated a Phase 3 study of bempedoic acid in patients with hyperlipidemia

(-) WMB (-17.71%) Deal with Energy Transfer Equity (ETE) will not be restructured

(-) BWA (-9.52%) Issued guidance for Q1 and fiscal 2016 that was mostly below analysts' expectations
